IRC.name: Intelligence Reconnaissance Capability
options: 0 - Could not obtain valid intelligence information
1 - Have the ability to collect basic asset information and network information
2 - Strong asset collection ability, able to find remote and vulnerable assets; strong organizational personnel reconnaissance ability, able to find key social work targets

3 - Be able to fully grasp the intelligence of the target organization, operations, collaboration, personnel, assets, security, network architecture, etc. through active and passive means, and formulate targeted attack plans.

4 - Under the premise that the target is not aware of the target, it can grasp the whole picture of the target and the details of the target, accurately draw the attack path, and quickly and accurately find the stronghold establishment plan.

WC.name: Weaponization Capability
options: 0 - no programming or programming ability
1 - Ability to write simple script EXP
2 - Ability to write more complex penetration tools
3 - Able to develop C2, automated penetration platform
4 - Ability to design and implement Stuxnet, Bvp47 level weapons

VMEC.name: Vulnerability Mining and Exploitation Capability
options: 0 - No exploitable loopholes can be found
1 - Able to exploit general vulnerabilities in applications and exploit them successfully
2 - Ability to mine and exploit highly complex vulnerabilities in applications
3 - Ability to mine common component or middleware vulnerabilities and exploit them successfully
4 - Ability to mine operating system and common system component-level vulnerabilities and exploit them successfully

ATDC.name: Anti Threat Detection Capability
options: 0 - no threat detection adversarial capability
1 - Able to bypass WAF and exploit the vulnerability without warning
2 - Can bypass anti-virus software to achieve C2 online without warning
3 - Low threat perception during RBI and intranet lateral movement
4 - In the case of extremely strong defensive strength, non-perceptual, long-term, and stable target action can be achieved after target breakthrough

SEC.name: Social Engineering Capability
options: 0 - cannot implement successful social work
1 - Successful social worker with access to general staff
2 - Successful social work and access to security awareness trained non-security practitioners
3 - Successful social work and authorization for those who are engaged in security positions
4 - Able to successfully social work and gain access to the most professional security engineers

PPC.name: Permission Persistence Capability
options: 0 - Unable to maintain stronghold authority persistence
1 - Ability to implement basic command execution on the base
2 - Implement permission maintenance in case of reboot
3 - Ability to elevate stronghold privileges to execute more commands
4 - Privilege Maintenance After Emergency Response

TCC.name: Tunnel Construction Capability
options: 0 - Unable to build a smooth and stable tunnel
1 - Able to build a simple springboard to achieve C2 online and intranet roaming
2 - Ability to build multi-level springboard tunnels according to the needs of the environment
3 - Ability to hide springboard traffic into normal network traffic to achieve threat insensitivity
4 - On the basis of the former, it can penetrate the target multi-layer intranet and use a variety of different protocols to build a stable tunnel link

LMC.name: Lateral Movement Capability
options: 0 - The base is the end point, no continuous network expansion capability
1 - The identity and location of the base can be confirmed through information collection, and useful intelligence information can be obtained
2 - On the basis of the former, it can spy on the intranet without perception, and find the lateral movement path or target
3 - On the basis of the former, all login credentials of the base can be obtained and the credentials can be successfully used
4 - On the basis of the former, non-perceptual lateral movement is realized through various complex technical means such as puddles, social work, and supply chains.

GAT.name: Goal Achievement Time
options: 0 - Incomplete breakthrough control of target system
1 - Target breakthrough not completed, but control of multiple core system breakthroughs
2 - Complete the breakthrough control of some targets within a limited time
Break control of major core targets within 3-1-3 weeks
Break control of major core targets within 4-1-3 days

GAC.name: Goal Achievement Cost
options: 0 - Severely making ends meet
1 - great cost (nuclear 0day, etc.)
2 - Larger cost (generic 0day, etc.)
3 - lower cost
4 - almost no cost

GAA.name: Goal Action Ability
options: 0 - Unable to achieve target action on target
1 - Partial data leakage to target achieved
2 - Implemented partial operational effects on targets
3 - Full data leakage to target achieved
4 - Data exfiltration can be accomplished without perception, or cause long-term lasting effects

IEMC.name: Information Event Management Capability
options: 0 - The implementation of log management specifications is not in place, and a large number of logs are missing
1 - Decentralized logging and event tracing capabilities
2 - There is a centralized security log and event management system
3 - Ability to classify and summarize log events, identify, rate and alert on threats
4 - Ability to systematically log incident response and security operations

SUMC.name: Software Update Management Capability
options: 0 - No software update management capabilities, with a large number of long-term critical vulnerabilities
1 - Timely security updates can be made to the operating system patches of production servers
2 - Unified management and timely security updates for software commonly used in development, operation and maintenance
3 - Version management and timely security updates can be performed on systems, container service programs, and middleware
4 - Version management and timely security updates can be performed on the components that the application depends on and references

TIBC.name: Threat Identification Blocking Capability
options: 0 - No threat identification blocking facility
1 - There are border traffic protection and blocking facilities
2 - On the basis of the former, there are internal traffic protection and blocking facilities
3 - On the basis of the former, there are endpoint protection and blocking facilities
4 - On the basis of the former, there are security orchestration and automated response facilities

BSMC.name: Baseline Security Management Capabilities
options: 0 - No baseline security management capability
1 - With service security configuration and audit log baseline management
2 - Based on the former, there is access control baseline management
3 - On the basis of the former, there are account permissions and authentication authorization baseline management
4 - On the basis of the former, there are security testing and evaluation processes for services, networks, and supply chains

ASMC.name: Account Security Management Capabilities
options: 0 - no unified identity management capability
1 - Unified account management and authentication
2 - More secure authentication techniques (go password or MFA etc.)
3 - Unified Identity Management Based on Trusted Devices
4 - Dynamic Adaptive and Continuous Authentication

PSMC.name: Privilege Security Management Capability
options: 0 - no authority unified management capability
1 - Unified functional granularity rights management (authorization, authentication, etc.)
2 - Ongoing Evaluation and Online Governance of Privilege Minimization
3 - Unified data granularity rights management
4 - Continuous Evaluation and Dynamic Control of Privilege Abuse Prevention

NACC.name: Network Access Control Capability
options: 0 - the network does not perform any access control
1 - The office network is isolated from the production network and accessed through the bastion machine
2 - External customer service has network isolation from internal staff service
3 - There is network isolation between services
4 - has more fine-grained micro-isolation capabilities

ETTA.name: External Threat Traffic Awareness
options: 0 - almost no perception
1 - has a small amount of perception
2 - has moderate perception
3 - has a lot of perception
4 - almost all perception

EHAA.name: External Harpoon Attack Awareness
options: 0 - no perception
1 - Attack event sensed and attack sample captured
2 - Perceived the attack event and traced out all the phishing personnel and alerted
3 - Perceived that the phishing recruited employees, extracted terminal samples, and restored the attack method
4 - On the basis of the former, the landing, execution and online actions of the fishing Trojan can be quickly sensed, and can be blocked in time

PPAA.name: Proximity Penetration Attack Awareness
options: 0 - almost no perception
1 - After a successful attack, determine the path of the near-source penetration attack through source tracing.

2 - Successfully found traces of near-source penetration through technical monitoring and administrative means, including but not limited to collecting U disks, capturing HID attacks, wifi blasting, etc.

3 - On the basis of the former, it can analyze in detail the attack methods and attack processes used by the attackers, including but not limited to the analysis of attack methods against wifi and the analysis of Trojan horses
4 - On the basis of the former, it has independent near-source perception capabilities to quickly detect near-source attacks and block them in time.

ITTA.name: Intranet Threat Traffic Awareness
options: 0 - almost no perception
1 - Can perceive indiscriminate full intranet scanning behavior, identify abnormal points and quickly locate the scanning source IP
2 - Based on traffic characteristics, small-scale intranet scans such as C segment can be captured, and the target and purpose can be restored.
3 - Perception of partial credential exploitation and lateral movement, or data exfiltration
4 - Perception of almost the entire attack process, and the encrypted C2 channel used by the attacker

EMA.name: Endpoint Malware Awareness
options: 0 - almost no perception
1 - There is a smooth feedback channel for employee security issues, and terminal attacks are quickly detected
2 - Ability to sense endpoint attacks through endpoint detection responses, threat traffic analysis
3 - Capable of capturing attack samples, extracting effective network or host IOC and implementing monitoring and blocking capability deployment
4 - Complete automated sandbox analysis, threat identification intelligence and strategies, security orchestration and automated threat handling mechanisms

EABA.name: Endpoint Abnormal Behavior Awareness
options: 0 - almost no perception
1 - Able to perceive large-scale network scanning behavior for this machine and alert
2 - Able to perceive the network password blasting behavior against this machine and give an alarm
3 - Ability to perceive abnormal operation behavior of privileged accounts, sensitive files, and processes on the terminal
4 - Able to sense abnormal remote login behavior between terminals

TDR.name: Threat Detection Rate
TDR.description: The coverage rate of high-risk threats actually identified by the defender through manual or other means after the system detects the threat.
options: 0 - no checkouts made
1 - detection rate: 0 < N <= 25%
2 - Detection rate: 25% < N <= 50%
3 - Detection rate: 50% < N <= 80%
4 - Detection rate: 80% < N <= 100%

TITR.name: Threat Identification Timeliness Rate
TITR.description: The timely rate of high-risk threats actually identified by the defender through manual or other means after the system detects the threat.
options: 0 - no timely identification (more than 12 hours)
1 - Timely rate: 0 < N <= 25%
2 - Timeliness: 25% < N <= 50%
3 - Timeliness: 50% < N <= 80%
4 - Timeliness: 80% < N <= 100%

THC.name: Threat Handling Capability
options: 0 - no disposition is done
1 - Disposal rate: 0 < N <= 25%
2 - Disposal rate: 25% < N <= 50%
3 - Disposal rate: 50% < N <= 80%
4 - Disposal rate: 80% < N <= 100%

TDTR.name: Threat Disposal Timely Rate
options: 0 - No timely disposal (greater than 12 hours)
1 - Timely rate: 0 < N <= 25%
2 - Timeliness: 25% < N <= 50%
3 - Timeliness: 50% < N <= 80%
4 - Timeliness: 80% < N <= 100%

TAC.name: Threat Analysis Capability
options: 0 - no threat analysis capability
1 - Ability to accurately identify threats and extract valid IOCs
2 - Has automated threat analysis and intelligence sharing mechanisms
3 - Able to perform complex threat analysis, restore attack methods and targets
4 - With automated threat analysis technology and professional reverse analysis capabilities, a complete analysis report can be formed

IPTC.name: Intrusion Path Traceability Capability
options: 0 - no intrusion path traceability
1 - Attack path restoration 0 - 25%
2 - Attack path restoration 25% - 50%
3 - Attack path restoration 50% - 80%
4 - Attack Path Recovery 80% - 100%

ATCC.name: Attacker Traceability and Countermeasure Capability
options: 0 - hardly any useful information can be traced back to the source
1 - Attacker's C2 server IP or springboard IP is traced
2 - Attackers commonly use virtual identities or real IPs in China to be traced
3 - Attacker's attack asset or computer is reversely controlled
4 - The real identity information of the attacker is traced to the source

DEC.name: Deception and Entrapment Capabilities
options: 0 - no deception trapping ability
1 - Build a high-fidelity honeypot in the network
2 - A highly simulated honeynet is built in the network, which can introduce attackers into the honeynet
3 - Dynamic honeynet capability, which can direct all attacker traffic into the honeynet from the production environment

4 - It has perfect secret spraying, honey tagging and honey application customization, and honey farm management capabilities, which can realize active attraction, dynamic adaptation and anti-trapping capabilities

OL.name: Offensive Level
OL.description: The highest level of technology used in the assessment path?
options: 0 - Equivalent to entry-level hackers
1 - Equivalent to ordinary level hackers or tools, script hackers
2 - Equivalent to hackers proficient in penetration technology
3 - Need more professional team cooperation
4 - Equivalent to a national APT hacker team

OD.name: Offensive Difficulty
OD.description: The highest difficulty in solving the problem in the entire evaluation path?
options: 0 - Almost no difficulty
1 - A bit difficult
2 - More difficult
3 - Very Difficult
4 - Hardly handle

TR.name: Target Reach
TR.description: Has the expected goal been achieved?
options: 0 - Basically not reached
1 - A small amount
2 - Medium amount
3 - Mass reached
4 - Fully achieved

AL.name: Anti-traceability Level
AL.description: What is the attacker's anti-traceability Level?
options: 0 - The attacker's real identity information is traced
1 - The attacker's attack asset or computer is reversely controlled
2 - Attacker's common virtual identities or domestic real IPs to be traced
3 - The attacker's C2 server IP or jump IP is traced
4 - Almost no useful information can be traced

PL.name: Prevention Level
PL.description: Ability to intercept critical paths in the assessment process
options: 0 - Almost no interception
1 - Slightly intercepted
2 - Strong interception
3 - Very strong interception
4 - Almost hard to break through

DL.name: Detection Level
DL.description: The ability to detect cyber threats on critical paths in the assessment process
options: 0 - Hardly detect threats
1 - Threats of sporadic attacks on non-critical assets detected
2 - A small number of critical path threats detected
3 - A large number of critical path threats detected
4 - Almost all threats detected

RL.name: Response Level
RL.description: Resilience, repair and emergency response to the occupied system？
options: 0 - Basically unable to move (More than one week)
1 - Slow response (more than 24 hours)
2 - Response is relatively timely (within 24 hours)
3 - Response is close to real time (within 2 hours)
4 - Real-time response (within 30 minutes)

TL.name: Traceability Level
TL.description: Whether the attacker can be traced effectively
options: 0 - Basically cannot be traced effectively
1 - The DNS, C2 and other information used by the attacker can be found
2 - Can find the attacker's lateral movement path information
3 - Part of the real IP or virtual identity of the attacker can be found
4 - The attacker can be successfully traced and countered

VD.name: Vulnerability Discoverability
VD.description: Discoverability of critical vulnerabilities in the penetration path
options: 0 - Almost hard to find out
1 - Difficulty
2 - Medium
3 - Easy
4 - Automated tools available

VE.name: Vulnerability Exploitability
VE.description: Exploitability of critical vulnerabilities in the penetration path
options: 0 - Almost hard to use
1 - Difficulty
2 - Medium
3 - Easy
4 - Automated tools available

VL.name: Vulnerability Lethality
VL.description: Maximum lethality of critical vulnerabilities in the penetration path
options: 0 - Basically no harm
1 - Lower lethality
2 - A certain degree of lethality
3 - Wide range of lethality
4 - Extremely wide lethality

VDW.name: Vulnerability Disclosure Window
VDW.description: Maximum exposure time window for critical vulnerabilities in the penetration path?
options: 0 - No disclosure
1 - Small-scale dissemination disclosure
2 - Public disclosure less than 3 days
3 - Public disclosure more than 3 days
4 - Public disclosure more than 2 weeks

LC.name: Loss of Confidentiality
LC.description: How much data could be disclosed and how sensitive is it?
options: 0 - A small amount of non-sensitive data can be disclosed
1 - A small amount of sensitive data can be disclosed
2 - A medium amount of sensitive data can be disclosed
3 - A large amount of sensitive data can be disclosed
4 - All sensitive data can be disclosed

LI.name: Loss of Integrity
LI.description: How much data could be corrupted and how damaged is it?
options: 0 - A small amount of non-core data can be damaged
1 - A small amount of core data can be damaged
2 - A large amounts of non-core data can be damaged
3 - A large amount of core data can be damaged
4 - All data can be damaged can be damaged

LA.name: Loss of Availability
LA.description: How much service could be lost and how vital is it?
options: 0 - Can interrupt a small amount of non-core business
1 - Can interrupt a amount of core business
2 - Can interrupt a medium amount of the core business
3 - Can interrupt a large amount of core business
4 - Can interrupt almost All important business

FD.name: Financial Damage
FD.description: How much financial damage will result from an exploit?
options: 0 - Less than the cost to fix the vulnerability
1 - No effect on annual profit
2 - A certain effect on annual profit
3 - Significant effect on annual profit
4 - Huge effect on annual profit

RD.name: Reputation Damage
RD.description: Will it cause damage to the corporate reputation and damage the business?
options: 0 - Minimal damage
1 - Loss of large customers or a large number of customers
2 - Loss of goodwill
3 - Brand damage
4 - Major brand damage

CI.name: Compliance Impact
CI.description: What is the risk of violations that arise from problems or malicious actions by an attacker?
options: 0 - Almost no violation
1 - Minor violation
2 - Clear violation
3 - High profile violation
4 - Serious violation or illegality

DLC.name: Development Life Circle
DLC.description: Are there security issues in the software development life cycle?
options: 0 - Basically did not consider security issues
1 - There are more security process issues
2 - There are certain security process issues
3 - There are a small number of security process issues
4 - Almost no security process issues

OLC.name: Operation Life Circle
OLC.description: Are there any security issues in the O&M life cycle?
options: 0 - Basically did not consider security issues
1 - There are more security process issues
2 - There are certain security process issues
3 - There are a small number of security process issues
4 - Almost no security process issues

ESA.name: Employment Security Awareness
ESA.description: Do most employees have security awareness during the assessment process?
options: 0 - Almost all staff have no security awareness
1 - Most of the employees in key positions have weak-security awareness
2 - A small number of employees in key positions have weak security awareness
3 - Most of the employees in key positions have high-security awareness
4 - All employees have a high level of security awareness
